utterances: At a harbor in Saco, Maine, a 45-foot commercial fishing boat, the Ocean Spray, is motoring up to the pier.
(Soundbite of fishing boat)
Craig Pendleton owns and captains this boat, which drags big nets for bottom fish like flounder and cod.
He says the higher fuel costs are just hammering guys like him.
It's getting to the point where it's really frustrating, and you know, I don't need to make a million dollars, but I sure would like to have something at the end of the week.
That's not an exaggeration, that fuel's become such a huge expense that in fishing harbors around New England fishermen are having trouble making any money at all.
Up the coast in Portland, Maine, boat owner Brian Pearce has just unloaded his catch of cod and other ground fish from a three-day trip.
For instance, this last trip here, you know, we might have made 3,000 bucks altogether.
It's going to cost us about 2,400 bucks in fuel, food and ice.
And how much of that 2,400 bucks is fuel, and then, you know, what are you paying per day?
Oh, I would say 2,200 of it was for fuel.
That leaves $600 for myself, another man and the expense and cost of a boat.
So Pearce just spent three days at sea working around the clock and doesn't have much to show for it.
Just a year or so ago, when fuel was about half the price, Pearce would have had an extra $1,000 in his pocket after a trip like this.
Go back five or six years and he'd have had another $1,500 in his pocket, because back then...
I was paying below a dollar a gallon for fuel, and right now I think it's around 4.25, 4.30 a gallon.
So I mean that's four times as much as it was five years ago.
So for many types of commercial fishermen, the spike in fuel prices has turned the economics of fishing on its head.
(Soundbite of auction)
A hundred yard away down the pier, the daily fish auction is underway in this refrigerated warehouse.
You can see why fishermen like Pearce are in trouble.
(Soundbite of banging)
The fish here gets unloaded, packed on ice and sold to the highest bidder.
The problem is, there's no way to pass along the higher fuel cost.
Yeah, it's an auction.
The auction mechanism works quite well.
Bert Jongerden is the general manager of the Portland Fish Exchange, and he says fishermen can only get what customers will pay, and those customers have a lot of choices.
They can usually get cheap farmed catfish or shrimp from Asia, or they could just eat more chicken.
They're only going to pay so much for Atlantic cod.
Whatever market forces are working that day, that's what the price will be, you know, and it's not like a boat can say, you know, I need to charge an extra 50 cents a pound for fuel.
You know, the market won't work that way.
Jongerden heads outside to the fish pier, where a bunch of hulking 70-foot fishing boats are tied up.
He says half the fishing fleet here isn't working.
The owners say with fuel so expensive, it just doesn't pay to leave the dock.
This whole fuel has just got a big cascading effect on everybody.
It's just - you know, the boats can't fish because they can't make any money.
The crews on the fishing boats have all decided they can't work because, I mean, no one works for nothing.
The ice house is affected because they're not selling ice.
The boats aren't fishing.
They're not selling fuel because boats aren't fishing.
So I mean this whole little economic model on the waterfront is just in a big lurch right now.
Economists and fishermen both predict that if fuel prices stay this high, there's going to be a shake-out in the industry.
Some fishermen will be okay - say, scallopers, who get a good price for their catch - but a lot of others will go out of business.
Brian Pearce will probably be one of them.
Already last year he sold his federal fishing permit for the bigger of his two boats; he says he'd like to sell both of his boats, but he's having trouble.
Then the question is, well, how do you reduce demand?
And there's two ways.
One is you become more efficient, cars that get better gas mileage, you know, houses that use energy more efficiently.
I mean, there's all sorts of ways to do that, and that's one side.
The other side is to find other fuels and technologies that aren't oil, bio-fuels or you can begin exploring hydrogen.
Both these pathways of conservation and alternatives reduce your demand for oil and in the medium and long-term will reduce the price.

But I have to ask, if you're able to reduce the price of oil substantially, does the whole cycle start all over again because then people will say, gas is so cheap, I might, well, you can fill in that blank.
Precisely, and this is what we've seen in the past.

I mean, those high prices you were talking about in the '70s, everyone got the fear of God in them, and Detroit began, with a little prodding from Congress, began making fuel-efficient cars, consumers began behaving as if there was an end to oil.
And then in the mid-'80s our demand for oil dropped so significantly, there was a glut of oil in the market.
The price dropped.
It went from in the $70.00 range down to, you know, 10 and 15 dollars.
And people just said, well, there's no problem.
But high prices are good because high prices indicate that the market is moving toward a new state of equilibrium.

It may take a while to get there, but high prices encourage conservation, they encourage the development of new technologies, they encourage the movement of our economy away from a fuel that everyone knows is unsustainable.
Paul Roberts, author of The End of Oil on the Edge of a Perilous New World, speaking from KUOW in Seattle.
Mr. Roberts, thanks very much.
Oh, it's my pleasure.
An historic change is taking place in England.
A new law requires that from now on, all employers automatically enroll workers in retirement savings plans, or pensions.
As part of our series Your Money and Your Life, NPR's Chris Arnold reports.
One day not so long ago, the phone rang on Tim Jones's desk.
He's a successful bank executive in London, so he's a pretty busy guy.
I got a call from a headhunter.
And they said, don't hang up, Tim, it's pensions.
And I laughed and said, look, I am going to hang up because pensions are very dull.
And he said, you won't think so after you've been to see me.
The headhunter told Jones that the government wanted him to run an investment fund but on a massive scale, an investment fund for the working population of England.

How often do you get a chance to build something from scratch that will only work if it does a really great job of helping millions of people and hundreds of thousands of employers create a great retirement savings solution?
So the U.K.
had passed this auto enrollment system for all companies.
Workers pay into what's basically like a 401(k) plan.
But they needed a good low-cost investment fund to handle the money so employers would have a smart, safe way for their workers to invest.
This fund - if it worked - was basically going to help an entire nation of people to build wealth.
I thought, wow, this is going to be hard but a huge amount of fun.
I was sold.
And Jones went on to create the National Employment Savings Trust.
It's a nonprofit, now managing investments for millions of workers in the U.K.
One reason that Jones said that savings is hard is that a lot of working-class people think that they just can't afford to save.
At an outdoor market in London, 30-year-old Garfield Bloomfield is selling vegetables.
And he smiles at me like I'm making a joke when I ask him if he's saving for retirement yet.
I'm not really saving for the future.
I would like to save for the future obviously, but at the moment, I'm just working to get by really.
Psychologists and behavioral economists say that there are all kinds of reasons that people don't start saving for retirement until it's too late.
And some of them are very good reasons.
My wife is not working at the moment because she decided to go back into studies.
so I'm not really saving towards the future.
Because you're just not making enough to have any extra...
Not making enough, and I've got kids to take care of, so it's like, yeah.
Of course, in the U.S.
wages have been stagnant.
A lot of people here, too, feel like they're just scraping by.
But here's the thing.

If you take someone like Bloomfield and enroll him automatically in a retirement savings plan - that is, he doesn't do anything at all, but money starts coming out of his paycheck - the odds are that he'll keep saving even though right now he thinks he can't afford it.
And because of the new law, Bloomfield's employer soon will have to do just that.
Charlotte Clark is the top government official for retirement savings in the U.K.
She met me at the market here and explained that over the past year or so, a lot of workers have already been enrolled.
We still got another couple of years to roll out to all employers.
So we still got some way to go.
But we've got 5 million people saving.
And this is the kind of amazing thing - right?
- that people can opt out if they want.
They could say no, no, no, give me all my money, thank you very much.
But when you sign people up, you've been finding that they actually stick with it.
Yeah, we're seeing over 90 percent of people sticking with it.
So that's 9 out of 10 people are deciding that this is the right thing for them.
And Clark says an even higher percentage of lower income workers stick with it.
It's made very clear to them that if they opt out, they're losing free money from their employer.
Workers start just by putting in 2 percent of their salary into a retirement account.
Employers match a portion of that, and the total with the employer match increases over time to at least 8 percent.
Clark said she's especially happy about the lower income workers.
Yeah, if we look around, what do we see?
You know, people who are working for relatively small businesses - we've got a pork pie shop sign just behind you.
I don't think anyone's ever made too much of a fortune kind of selling pork pies.
And for tips on how to save and invest in a smart way, check out our series Your Money and Your Life at npr.org.
